speaker: Barbara Smith
sentence: We're using um we're using actually clinically and clinical and research tools um to translate light and sound.

speaker: Barbara Smith
sentence: And so we use electrodes as our wave guides to um to send light down, uh target a molecule of interest in the in the deep tissue um that uh might have a some genetic marker.

speaker: Barbara Smith
sentence: And then um we we can get both sound wave and light wave back up the electrode.

speaker: Barbara Smith
sentence: And so all all we need um is all of our um all of our software part uh and then the hardware part that we need is um the laser, uh optical fiber, any of optics that we need and then we um we trans transfer that light down.

speaker: Barbara Smith
sentence: And we use that both in in research applications and then we also um use that in clinical applications.

speaker: Barbara Smith
sentence: And so we uh we develop um integrated systems for like pipels uh so for endometrial cancer for instance that um right now they go in blind and um an OBGYN will take out cells um in in throughout the uterus, but it's just a vacuum system that they'll place in and they'll um release a vacuum and then that tube will be removed manually.

speaker: Barbara Smith
sentence: And so we've integrated like an optical and acoustic system into that so that they can have visual guidance and eyes where they're currently going in blind.

speaker: Barbara Smith
sentence: And so um how we um re I I would say um reposition the light as we go at a 90 degree angle, we'll we'll place an optical fiber in with um with some kind of redirection.

speaker: Barbara Smith
sentence: And so we can get um both optics and acoustics coming from the surrounding area so we can look for different different things both endogenous, so like um that hemoglobin and and different kinds of areas where there's increased vasculature um and acoustic information as well and they're also doing transactional ultrasounds.

speaker: Barbara Smith

speaker: Barbara Smith
sentence: Yeah, so we do it's electrophysiology.

speaker: Barbara Smith
sentence: So um the micropipette electrode um was developed I think it's around the 1960s and um they record neuronal activity.

speaker: Barbara Smith
sentence: It's a high resolution recording of typically single neurons um and their activity level um with the with the um basically I won't go into detail.

speaker: Barbara Smith
sentence: Um so the electrode is placed into the brain and um it's typically done either um blind or um using optical microscopy approaches from from external sources.

speaker: Barbara Smith
sentence: So uh a microscope on the outside.

speaker: Barbara Smith
sentence: And and so what ends up happening is if you have um if you work with this blind, you would use like probably a DIC microscope and um you can do this in vivo and the electrode is placed in and uh positive pressure is is pushed into the electrode as it's moved through the brain tissue so that that electrode doesn't get clogged.

speaker: Barbara Smith
sentence: The tip of the electrode is about um one to three microns in diameter and that electrode is is moved little very very very slowly into the brain um and there's no way to target selective cells of interest using the blind approach, but you can get deeper, right?

speaker: Barbara Smith
sentence: So um the only way the most basic way that they know that they've hit a cell of interest is by creating a connection between that electrode and that cell.

speaker: Barbara Smith
sentence: So they place it from a positive pressure and then we make a negative pressure from that.

speaker: Barbara Smith
sentence: We create a bleb, so it sucks up part of that membrane of the cell.

speaker: Barbara Smith
sentence: Um we um increase the pressure and it opens up the cell membrane so that there's a direct connection between that electrode and the fluids within the electrode and the cell um solution.

speaker: Barbara Smith
sentence: And and what ends up happening is the um it ends up being able to record that cell, but you don't know what cell you're hitting until you start recording it.

speaker: Barbara Smith
sentence: And if you've started recording the wrong cell, you have to remove that micropipette electrode um throw it out, place a new one in and then enter into the brain one more time.

speaker: Barbara Smith
sentence: And so uh it's kind of a hunt and peck process.

speaker: Barbara Smith
sentence: You can get deeper and people can record very well uh neuroscientists have been recording like that for for decades.

speaker: Barbara Smith
sentence: Um but lately with two photon microscopy, you can get down to about a millimeter and you can genetically alter or place in different kinds of dyes and and selectively target neurons up to a millimeter.

speaker: Barbara Smith
sentence: But past the millimeter from the cortical surface, um there are minimal ways to do it.

speaker: Barbara Smith
sentence: So you can suction out a portion of the brain.

speaker: Barbara Smith
sentence: Um that's one way to do it and then the animal is still alive and you can move down um and you can do within a millimeter of whatever area you've sectioned.

speaker: Barbara Smith
sentence: Um or if you're coming from the top, you can see cells about within a millimeter of of where that surface is.

speaker: Barbara Smith
sentence: If you're exceptional if you're doing three photon or multi photon, you can get maybe two millimeters.

speaker: Barbara Smith
sentence: Um it's a little bit rough.

speaker: Barbara Smith
sentence: Um but the way that we're doing this is oh oh is we're integrating light and sound into that micropipette electrode so you don't need a microscope on the outside to guide that cell.

speaker: Barbara Smith
sentence: And so um we can get uh stains and genetic um uh genetic contrast throughout the brain and now we can we can tap into cells um of interest at at depths beyond one millimeter as deep as that.

speaker: Barbara Smith
sentence: So we're combining um blind and an imaging guided approach by doing this, but without the microscope on the outside.
